paragraphs.zh-tw: Imagine that you're a pig farmer. You live on a small farmin the Philippines. Your animals are your family'ssole source of income -- as long as they're healthy.
paragraphs.en: 想像一下你是一個養豬人， 你住在菲律賓的一個小農場。 你的動物是你家庭的主要收入來源， 只要它們保持健康。

paragraphs.zh-tw: You know that any day, one of your pigs can catch the flu, the swine flu. Living in tight quarters,one pig coughing and sneezing may soon lead to the next pigcoughing and sneezing, until an outbreak of swine fluhas taken over your farm.
paragraphs.en: 你知道總會有一天， 其中一隻豬會得禽流感， 豬流感。 它們住在狹小的住所裡，一隻豬咳嗽和打噴嚏， 遲早會造成下一隻豬咳嗽和打噴嚏， 直達豬流感爆發，佔領農場。

paragraphs.zh-tw: If it's a bad enough virus, the health of your herd may be gonein the blink of an eye. If you called in a veterinarian, he or she would visit your farmand take samples from your pigs' noses and mouths.
paragraphs.en: 如果是一個很嚴重的病毒， 你豬群的健康可能就在眨眼間灰飛煙滅。 如果你聯繫一個獸醫， 他或她可能會造訪你的農場， 並從豬的鼻子和口腔中採集樣本，

paragraphs.zh-tw: But then they would have to driveback into the city to test those samplesin their central lab. Two weeks later,you'd hear back the results.
paragraphs.en: 但是接下來，他們需要開車回城市， 在他們的大型實驗室中測試樣本， 兩週後，你會得到結果，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Two weeks may be just enough timefor infection to spread and take away your way of life. But it doesn't have to be that way.
paragraphs.en: 兩周時間可能足夠疾病傳染， 並奪走你賴以為生的東西。 但是事情並不一定會發展成那樣，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Today, farmers can takethose samples themselves. They can jump right into the penand swab their pigs' noses and mouths with a little filter paper, place that little filter paperin a tiny tube, and mix it with some chemicalsthat will extract genetic material from their pigs' noses and mouths.
paragraphs.en: 現在，農場主們可以自己採集樣本， 他們可以直接用筆和一張小濾紙，擦豬的鼻子和口腔， 把濾紙放在一個試管內， 並加入一些能夠提取他們豬的鼻子和口腔基因的化學材料，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And without leaving their farms, they take a drop of that genetic material and put it into a little analyzersmaller than a shoebox, program it to detect DNA or RNAfrom the swine flu virus, and within one hour get back the results,visualize the results. This reality is possible because today we're living in the eraof personal DNA technology.
paragraphs.en: 並且不需要離開農場， 取一滴基因材料， 放入一個比鞋盒還小的分析器內， 設置並探測豬流感病毒內的DNA和RNA， 一小時之內就可取得結果，可視化的結果。 這一切是可能的， 因為我們活在一個個人DNA技術的時代。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Every one of us can actuallytest DNA ourselves. DNA is the fundamental moleculethe carries genetic instructions that help build the living world.
paragraphs.en: 每一個人都可以檢測自己的DNA。 DNA是攜帶遺傳信息結構的基本分子， 它幫助我們建造這個生機勃勃的世界。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Humans have DNA. Pigs have DNA.
paragraphs.en: 人類有DNA。 豬有DNA。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Even bacteria and someviruses have DNA too. The genetic instructions encoded in DNAinform how our bodies develop, grow, function.
paragraphs.en: 甚至細菌和一些病毒都有DNA。 DNA攜帶的遺傳信息結構告訴我們我們會怎樣進化，成長，運作。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And in many cases, that same informationcan trigger disease. Your genetic information is strung into a long and twistedmolecule, the DNA double helix, that has over three billion letters, beginning to end.
paragraphs.en: 在很多情況下，一樣的遺傳信息會造廠疾病。 你的基因信息 被串在一個長條的旋轉的分子中，DNA雙螺旋結構。 從頭到尾， 有超過30億個字母。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But the lines that carrymeaningful information are usually very short -- a few dozen to severalthousand letters long. So when we're looking to answera question based on DNA, we actually don't need to read all those three billionletters, typically.
paragraphs.en: 但是攜帶有意義信息的片段 通常其實很短—— 幾十到幾千個字母那麼長。 所以當我們需要根據DNA來解決一個問題的時候， 我們並不需要閱讀 所有30億個字母。

paragraphs.zh-tw: That would be like getting hungry at night and having to flip throughthe whole phone book from cover to cover, pausing at every line, just to find the nearest pizza joint. Luckily, three decades ago, humans started to invent tools that can find any specific lineof genetic information.
paragraphs.en: 這就像是在晚上感覺到飢餓， 要翻遍整本電話簿， 從頭到尾， 查看每一行， 只為了找到最近的披薩店。 幸運的是，三十年前， 人類開始研究能夠追蹤特定遺傳信息片段的工具，

paragraphs.zh-tw: These DNA machines are wonderful. They can find any line in DNA.
paragraphs.en: 這些DNA機器棒極了。 它們可以找到任何DNA的片段。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But once they find it, that DNA is still tiny, and surroundedby so much other DNA, that what these machines then dois copy the target gene, and one copy piles on top of another, millions and millionsand millions of copies, until that gene stands outagainst the rest; until we can visualize it, interpret it, read it, understand it, until we can answer: Does my pig have the flu? Or other questions buried in our own DNA: Am I at risk of cancer? Am I of Irish descent? Is that child my son? This ability to make copies of DNA,as simple as it sounds, has transformed our world. Scientists use it every dayto detect and address disease, to create innovative medicines, to modify foods, to assess whether our food is safe to eat or whether it's contaminatedwith deadly bacteria.
paragraphs.en: 但是一旦找到了片段， 微小的DNA依舊被無數其他DNA環繞著， 及其接下來做的，就是複製目標基因片段， 一段複製基因堆在另一段複製基因上， 它會複製上百萬份基因， 直到目標基因從中脫穎而出， 直到我們能夠把它可視化， 能夠翻譯它，讀取它，理解它， 直到我們能夠回答， 我的豬得流感了嗎？ 或則其他埋藏在我們基因裡的問題， 我有患癌風險嗎？ 我有愛爾蘭血統嗎? 那是我的兒子嗎？ 這種複製基因能力就和它聽起來一樣簡單， 這已經改變了我們的世界。 科學家每天都在使用這個技術，發現並解決疾病， 研發創新藥物， 改變食物， 評估我們的食物是否安全， 或者是否被致命細菌污染，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Even judges use the outputof these machines in court to decide whether someone is innocentor guilty based on DNA evidence. The inventor of this DNA-copying technique was awarded the Nobel Prizein Chemistry in 1993.
paragraphs.en: 甚至法官都會在法庭上使用這些機器的測驗結果， 根據DNA證物，來判斷誰是清白或有罪的。 基因複製技術的發明者 1993年獲得了化學諾貝爾獎。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But for 30 years, the power of genetic analysishas been confined to the ivory tower, or bigwig PhD scientist work. Well, several companies around the world are working on makingthis same technology accessible to everyday people like the pig farmer, like you.
paragraphs.en: 但是30年裡， 基因分析的能力一直被限制， 被有能力的博士科學家限制。 但是，世界上的一些公司， 正在研究如何讓這些技術 普及到像養豬人一樣的普通民眾中， 比如說你們。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I cofounded one of these companies. Three years ago, together with a fellow biologistand friend of mine, Zeke Alvarez Saavedra, we decided to make personal DNA machines that anyone could use.
paragraphs.en: 我和別人成立了其中一家公司， 三年前， 我和一個生物學家也是我的朋友， 齐克·阿尔瓦雷斯·萨维德拉， 我們決定研究每個人都可以使用的個人基因機器，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Our goal was to bring DNA scienceto more people in new places. We started working in our basements.
paragraphs.en: 我們的目標是把個人基因技術帶給更多人和地方。 我們在地下室裡開始工作。

paragraphs.zh-tw: We had a simple question: What could the world look like if everyone could analyze DNA? We were curious, as curious as you would have beenif I had shown you this picture in 1980. You would have thought, "Wow! I can now callmy Aunt Glenda from the car and wish her a happy birthday.
paragraphs.en: 我們有一個很簡單的問題： 如果每個人都能夠分析基因， 這個世界會變成什麼樣？ 我們很好奇， 就跟我在1980給你們展示這張照片一樣， 你會想 “哇， 我現在可以從車上給格蘭達姑姑打電話了， 並祝她生日快樂。

paragraphs.zh-tw: I can call anyone, anytime. This is the future!" Little did you know, you would tap on that phoneto make dinner reservations for you and Aunt Glendato celebrate together.
paragraphs.en: 我可以隨時給任何人打電話， 這就是未來！“ 你們不知道的是， 你可以點擊手機預定晚餐位置， 讓你和格蘭達姑姑能夠一起慶祝。

paragraphs.zh-tw: With another tap,you'd be ordering her gift. And yet one more tap, and you'd be "liking"Auntie Glenda on Facebook.
paragraphs.en: 再點擊一下，你就能夠給祂訂購禮物。 再點擊一下， 你就能在格蘭達姑姑的臉書上點讚。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And all of this,while sitting on the toilet. It is notoriously hard to predictwhere new technology might take us.
paragraphs.en: 這一切，都可以坐在馬桶上完成。 預測未來科技的發展方向是出了名的難，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And the same is truefor personal DNA technology today. For example, I could never have imagined that a truffle farmer, of all people, would use personal DNA machines.
paragraphs.en: 現在的個人基因技術也是一樣。 比如說，我從來不會想到 一個普普通通的松露養殖者， 能夠使用個人基因機器。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Dr. Paul Thomas growstruffles for a living. We see him pictured here, holding the first UK-cultivated trufflein his hands, on one of his farms.
paragraphs.en: 保羅托馬斯博士以種植松露衛生。 我們看他的照片， 手上抓著他農場之一種植的第一個英國產的松露，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Truffles are this delicacy that stems from a fungusgrowing on the roots of living trees. And it's a rare fungus.
paragraphs.en: 松露是這麼美味， 因為它是生長在樹上的真菌的莖， 而且還是稀有真菌。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Some species may fetch 3,000,7,000, or more dollars per kilogram. I learned from Paul that the stakes for a truffle farmercan be really high.
paragraphs.en: 一些品種能夠到每千克3000，7000，甚至更多美金， 我從保羅那裡學到， 當一個松露養殖者的賭注是很高的，

paragraphs.zh-tw: When he sources new trufflesto grow on his farms, he's exposed to the threatof knockoffs -- truffles that look and feellike the real thing, but they're of lower quality. But even to a trained eye like Paul's, even when looked at under a microscope, these truffles can pass for authentic.
paragraphs.en: 當他在農場中種植新的松露的時候， 他有可能會面臨山寨貨—— 看起來和摸起來像是松露. 但是它們質量都很低， 但是像保羅這樣訓練過的眼睛， 即使把它放在顯微鏡下觀察， 它們也有可能矇混過關，

paragraphs.zh-tw: So in order to growthe highest quality truffles, the ones that chefsall over the world will fight over, Paul has to use DNA analysis. Isn't that mind-blowing? I bet you will never lookat that black truffle risotto again without thinking of its genes.
paragraphs.en: 所以為了種植最高質量的松露， 那種世界上的廚師會為之爭奪的。 保羅需要用基因分析技術， 這不令人興奮嗎？ 我打賭下一次你看著一盤黑松露焗飯的時候， 一定會思考它的基因。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But personal DNA machinescan also save human lives. Professor Ian Goodfellow is a virologistat the University of Cambridge.
paragraphs.en: 但是個人基因技術還可以拯救人類生命。 伊恩·古德費洛教授是劍橋大學的一個病毒學家，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Last year he traveled to Sierra Leone. When the Ebola outbreakbroke out in Western Africa, he quickly realized that doctors therelacked the basic tools to detect and combat disease.
paragraphs.en: 去年，他去了塞拉利昂， 去年當埃博拉病毒在非洲西部爆發的時候， 他迅速的意識到那裡的醫生缺少基礎探測和抵禦病毒的工具。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Results could takeup to a week to come back -- that's way too long for the patientsand the families who are suffering. Ian decided to move his labinto Makeni, Sierra Leone.
paragraphs.en: 探測結果可能要花一周時間才會反饋—— 這對於經受痛苦的病人和家人來說太久了， 伊恩決定把他的實驗室搬到塞拉利昂的馬克尼，

paragraphs.zh-tw: Here we see Ian Goodfellow moving over 10 tons of equipmentinto a pop-up tent that he would equip to detectand diagnose the virus and sequence it within 24 hours. But here's a surprise: the same equipment that Ian could useat his lab in the UK to sequence and diagnose Ebola, just wouldn't work under these conditions.
paragraphs.en: 我們可以看到伊恩·古德費洛 搬運超過十噸重的設備到一個帳篷裡， 他能夠在24小時內組裝並開始探測和診斷病毒 及其基因序列。 但是，令人驚訝的是， 伊恩在他英國實驗室能夠使用的一樣的設備， 用來排序和診斷埃博拉基因的機器， 在這個條件下卻無法工作，

paragraphs.zh-tw: We're talking 35 Celsius heatand over 90 percent humidity here. But instead, Ian could usepersonal DNA machines small enough to be placedin front of the air-conditioning unit to keep sequencing the virus and keep saving lives.
paragraphs.en: 我說的可是35度的高溫和91%的濕度。 但是，伊恩可以使用個人基因機器， 小到能夠放置在空調前面， 繼續排列病毒基因， 繼續拯救生命。

paragraphs.zh-tw: This may seem likean extreme place for DNA analysis, but let's move on to an evenmore extreme environment: outer space. Let's talk about DNA analysis in space.
paragraphs.en: 這可能看起來對於分析基因是一個很極端的環境， 但是讓我們想想更極端的環境： 外太空。 讓我們來談談在外太空的基因分析。

paragraphs.zh-tw: When astronauts live aboardthe International Space Station, they're orbiting the planet250 miles high. They're travelingat 17,000 miles per hour.
paragraphs.en: 當宇航員們住在國際空間站的時候， 他們正在26500千米的高空， 以27400千米每小時的速度環繞地球。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Picture that -- you're seeing 15 sunsetsand sunrises every day. You're also living in microgravity, floating.
paragraphs.en: 想像一下， 每天，你還看見15次日出和日落， 而且你住在微重力下， 漂浮著。

paragraphs.zh-tw: And under these conditions,our bodies can do funky things. One of these things is thatour immune systems get suppressed, making astronauts more prone to infection.
paragraphs.en: 在這些情況下，我們的身體會做一些奇怪的反應， 其中的一件就是我們的免疫系統會被抑制， 讓宇航員們更容易被感染。

paragraphs.zh-tw: A 16-year-old girl, a high school student from New York,Anna-Sophia Boguraev, wondered whether changesto the DNA of astronauts could be relatedto this immune suppression, and through a science competitioncalled "Genes In Space," Anna-Sophia designed an experimentto test this hypothesis using a personal DNA machineaboard the International Space Station. Here we see Anna-Sophiaon April 8, 2016, in Cape Canaveral, watching her experiment launchto the International Space Station.
paragraphs.en: 一個16歲的女孩， 一個來自紐約的高中生，安娜索菲亞 博古拉， 她想知道宇航員基因的變化 是否和免疫系統的抑制有關， 通過一個叫做“太空基因”的比賽， 安娜索菲亞設計了一個實驗來檢驗這一個假說， 使用一個登上國際空間站的個人基因機器。 我們看到2016年8月8號，安娜索菲亞在斗篷狂歡節上， 看著她的實驗被送上國際空間站，

paragraphs.zh-tw: That cloud of smoke is the rocket that brought Anna-Sophia's experimentto the International Space Station, where, three days later, astronaut Tim Peakecarried out her experiment -- in microgravity. Personal DNA machines are nowaboard the International Space Station, where they can help monitorliving conditions and protect the lives of astronauts.
paragraphs.en: 那朵雲是火箭產生的煙霧， 那個火箭帶著安娜索菲亞的實驗飛往國際空間站， 在那裡，三天後， 宇航員蒂姆·皮克在微重力下進行了實驗， 國際空間站現在有了個人基因機器， 它能幫助監控生活環境， 並保護宇航員生命。

paragraphs.zh-tw: A 16-year-old designing a DNA experiment to protect the lives of astronauts may seem like a rarity,the mark of a child genius. Well, to me, it signalssomething bigger: that DNA technology is finallywithin the reach of every one of you.
paragraphs.en: 一個16歲的女孩設計了一個基因試驗， 並能夠保護宇航員生命， 這似乎很少見，但也表現了孩子的才智。 然而對於我來說，這代表著更重要的東西， 基因技術終於普及到每個人了。

paragraphs.zh-tw: A few years ago, a college student armedwith a personal computer could code an app, an app that is now a social networkwith more than one billion users. Could we be moving into a world of one personal DNA machine in every home? I know families who are alreadyliving in this reality.
paragraphs.en: 幾年前， 一個擁有個人電腦的大學生， 他編寫了一個程序， 一個現在擁有超過十億用戶的社交網絡。 我們能夠進入一個 每個家體都有一台個人基因機器的世界嗎？ 我知道一些已經實現這個的家庭，

paragraphs.zh-tw: The Daniels family, for example, set up a DNA lab in the basementof their suburban Chicago home. This is not a familymade of PhD scientists.
paragraphs.en: 比如說，丹尼爾的家庭， 在他們芝加哥城郊家裡的地下室裡建立了一個基因實驗室， 這不是一個擁有博士學位科學家的家庭，

paragraphs.zh-tw: This is a family like any other. They just like to spend time togetherdoing fun, creative things.
paragraphs.en: 這是一個普通的家庭。 他們只是喜歡花時間一起做一些有趣和有創造力的事情。

paragraphs.zh-tw: By day, Brian is an executiveat a private equity firm. At night and on weekends,he experiments with DNA alongside his kids, ages seven and nine, as a way to explore the living world.
paragraphs.en: 白天，布萊恩是一個私人企業的執行官， 晚上和週末，他和他七歲和九歲的孩子， 進行基因實驗， 當成一個探索世界的方式。

paragraphs.zh-tw: Last time I called them, they were checking out homegrown producefrom the backyard garden. They were testing tomatoesthat they had picked, taking the flesh of their skin,putting it in a test tube, mixing it with chemicals to extract DNA and then using their home DNA copier to test those tomatoesfor genetically engineered traits.
paragraphs.en: 上一次我給他們打電話的時候， 他們正在檢驗家裡後院種植的產品。 他們正在檢測他們挑選的番茄， 挑出番茄的外表皮和肉，放在檢測管裡， 和化學材料混合抽取基因， 然後用他們家裡的基因複製器， 檢測那些蕃茄的基因工程特徵。

paragraphs.zh-tw: For the Daniels family, the personal DNA machineis like the chemistry set for the 21st century. Most of us may not yetbe diagnosing genetic conditions in our kitchen sinks or doing at-home paternity testing.
paragraphs.en: 對於丹尼爾的家庭來說， 個人基因機器就像是21世紀的化學套裝， 我們中的大多數人都沒有檢測過廚房水槽內的基因條件。 或者在家裡做親子鑑定。

paragraphs.zh-tw: But we've definitely reacheda point in history where every one of you could actuallyget hands-on with DNA in your kitchen. You could copy, paste and analyze DNA and extract meaningfulinformation from it.
paragraphs.en: 但是我們一定已經到達了歷史的轉折點， 你們的每一個人都可以在廚房裡接觸基因。 你們可以複製，合成和分析基因 並從中取出有用的信息，

paragraphs.zh-tw: And it's at times like thisthat profound transformation is bound to happen; moments when a transformative,powerful technology that was before limitedto a select few in the ivory tower, finally becomes within the reachof every one of us, from farmers to schoolchildren. Think about the moment when phones stopped beingplugged into the wall by cords, or when computers left the mainframe and entered your home or your office.
paragraphs.en: 這些重大的改變 是時候要發生了。 這個顛覆性的技術 之前被選擇性的禁錮， 終於能夠普及到每一個人， 從農場主到學生。 想像一下， 當電話不再需要被插在牆上充電， 或者電腦不需要主機， 而且可以安置在家裡或辦公室。

paragraphs.zh-tw: The ripples of the personal DNA revolution may be hard to predict, but one thing is certain: revolutions don't go backwards, and DNA technology is already spreadingfaster than our imagination. So if you're curious, get up close and personalwith DNA -- today.
paragraphs.en: 波浪狀的個人基因革命 可能很難預測， 但是有一件事情是肯定的： 革命不會倒退， 基因技術的傳播已經比我們想像的要快。 所以如果你感到好奇， 現在就仔細的看看個人基因技術。

paragraphs.zh-tw: It is in our DNA to be curious. Thank you.
